editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.head: THE PREFACE.
div.p:
ABout the Yeere, 1608. Ieremy, Prince of Moldauia dying, left 3. Sonnes, Con≈øtantine, Alexander, and Bougdan, the elde≈øt of which being but 8. yeeres old, the Gouernment, during his Minority, was by the decea≈øed Father committed to his Vncle Simeon, who dying within three or foure yeeres after, Con≈øtantine the elde≈øt ≈øonne, according to his right, and ≈øupported by the Councell of his mother, vndertooke the gouernment. At which time there liued at Con≈øtantinople, one Tom≈øho or Stephen, who fal≈øly pretending to bee ≈øonne vnto Aron, who had been Prince of Moldauia before Ieremy, had by money and other ≈øini≈øter practices, framed
to his ends, Mehemet Bas≈øha, Lieutenant to the grand Vi≈øier (which is the highe≈øt Officer vnder the Turk) and by fal≈øly ≈øugge≈øting that Con≈øtantine refu≈øed to pay the yeerely tribute of forty thou≈øand Chequines to the great Turke, obtained from him an Army of 20000. men vnder the conduct of a Turki≈øh Generall, to expell Prince Con≈øtantine, and e≈øtabli≈øh him≈øelfe in the gouernment. And notwith≈øtanding Con≈øtantine endeuored to giue all due ≈øatisfaction to this Turki≈øh Generall, and made euident the fraud and fal≈øhood of Tom≈øho, yet hee being al≈øo corrupted by Tom≈øho's bribes and great promi≈øes, would admit no rea≈øon. Wherevpon Prince Con≈øtantine making head to defend him≈øelfe and Country, was in a Battaile ouercome, taken pri≈øoner, and after, ≈øeeking to e≈øcape, drowned in the Riuer Nie≈øtre. Tom≈øho, after this victory, being thru≈øt into the Gouernnment, & indeuoring to keepe by tyranny, what he had gotten by iniu≈øtice and v≈øurpation, the Nobility attempted by armes to free them≈øelues and their Country from his vn≈øpeakable cruelties, but with ≈øucce≈ø≈øe vnworthy their vertue;
for, by an ouerthrow, both his malice, and the Countries mi≈øery increa≈øed. In which di≈øa≈øter, the greate≈øt part of them fly into Poland, the refuge of the vnfortunate Prince≈ø≈øe with her remaining children, and the Tribunall from which their country was in iu≈øtice to expect a Gouernour: the Polonians hauing by ancient Articles, and capitulations betweene the Turke and them, to the end their Kingdome might not be preiudiced by that neighbour Prouince, which though Chri≈øtian, was yet tributary to the Turk, re≈øerued to them≈øelues the right and intere≈øt to name a Vaiuod, or Prince ouer that Country. And to this purpo≈øe the King of Poland ≈øent an Emba≈ø≈øadour to Con≈øtantinople, whom the Great Turke, contrary, to the Law of Nations, Turki≈øhly an≈øwered by detaining him pri≈øoner, and euer ≈øince hath threatened that mo≈øt Noble, and Chri≈øtian Kingdome, with vtter ≈øubuer≈øion, hauing (as it is probably conceiued) to that end drawne all his forces out of A≈øia, and made a greater leuy in Europe, then hath beene knowne in that Empire, con≈øi≈øting (by report)
of foure hundred thou≈øand men; an Armie ≈øufficient to ≈øatisfie the mo≈øt couetous, or religious Chri≈øtian Souldier with riches, or glory.

div.head: THE GREAT TVRKES LETTER.
div.p:
if thou doe≈øt de≈øire Our welfare, and art Friend to vs and Our Officer Lieutenant Generall of all our forces which we will ≈øend, Our Greeting. But thou ha≈øt long ≈øince broken Our friend≈øhip, and yet art neither ready nor fit to wage Warre, or fight battell again≈øt vs. But thou ha≈øt ≈øome ≈øecret aduice and intelligence with other confederate petty Kings, and their Coun≈øellors, to deliuer thee out of Our hands, and our Vicegerents power, wherein thou ha≈øt done vnadui≈øedly,
and indi≈øcreetly. If therfore thou thus per≈øeuere to oppo≈øe thy ≈øelfe again≈øt vs, then feare, for thy death, and the death of all thy people is determined. Wee tell thee, Wee will ouercome thee, from the ri≈øing of the Sun, to the going downe thereof, and we will ≈øhew Our Maie≈øty in our own per≈øon and ≈øight, vnto the vttermo≈øt parts of the earth; Our very thoughts ≈øhall be a terrour vnto thee, ≈øhewing that Wee will performe all that which Wee haue herein denounced. And Wee will make knowne vnto thee the powerfulne≈ø≈øe of our Dominions. And thou, O King, which putte≈øt thy tru≈øt in ≈øtrong Forts & Ca≈øtles, ≈øhalt haue experience of Our re≈øi≈øtle≈ø≈øe might. I will roote thee out altogether, and thou ≈øhalt behold this with thine owne eyes. Wherefore expect now no more friend≈øhip at my hands; put not thy hope in the ≈øtrength of thy walles, with thy owne forces and people. I will ruinate thee without any re≈øi≈øtance. I will de≈øtroy thy Cracouia, in ≈øigne of triumph, I will leaue there my bloudy ≈øword, that euery one ≈øhall take notice thereof, and my beliefe ≈øhall bee ≈øpread throughout all thy Dominions, and I will vtterly roote out the very remembrance of thy Crucified God. Let thy God bee angry, I
care not; He may thou helpe thee. Thy anointed (the Prie≈øts) I will ≈øurely put to the plague; Wolues and wilde Bea≈øts ≈øhall ≈øucke the bre≈øts of thy Women; thou ≈øhalt leaue and for≈øake thy Religion which thou now ha≈øt; that which remaineth of all things, ≈øhall bee con≈øumed with fire. Herewith re≈øt thou ≈øatisfied; I doe not tell thee now what I will doe; or meane to doe with thee; vnder≈øtand if thou wilt, or can≈øt.

div.head: THE KING OF POLAND HIS ANSVVERE.

opener.signed: SIGISMVND the third, by the grace of God King of Poland, Great Duke of Lithuania, Ru≈øsia, Pru≈øsia, Ma≈øouia, Samogitia, Liuonia, &c. and Hereditarie King of the Suecians, Gothes, and Vandales, one of the mo≈øt humble ≈øeruants of the True God, and of his Sonne IESVS CHRIST Crucified,

div.p:
We haue receiued thy Letter, full fraught with threats, and ≈øwolne with impieties again≈øt the Maie≈øtie of the mo≈øt
High God, whereunto wee had not vouch≈øafed an≈øwere, but that wee were per≈øwaded, our ≈øilence would haue been a meanes of cau≈øing thee to flatter thy ≈øelfe ≈øo much the more, el≈øe had Wee neglected thee like an Arch-enemy of God, as thou art. Wee haue therefore thought fit in ≈øome ≈øort to regard the Saluation of thy ≈øoule, giuing thee to know, that thou art no other then a meere man, in thy per≈øon more weake then many of thy followers; which ≈øhould cau≈øe thee to remember, that if it had not plea≈øed God to ingraue in the front of ≈øuch as rule, a kinde of awfull Maie≈øtie, whereby their ≈øubiects are kept in obedience; the good by reward, the euill and peruer≈øe by rigorous Lawes, and both the one and the other by Authoritie; it were impo≈ø≈øible they ≈øhould continue eminent aboue others. Thou then, who in thy ≈øelfe art but as other men, mu≈øt know, that there is a Supreme Power of more might then thine, which doth vphold thy e≈øtate, cau≈øing thee to bee re≈øpected by thy followers. This power proceeds from God
mo≈øt Good, mo≈øt Iu≈øt, mo≈øt Mighty, who pre≈ørueth it ≈øo long as Princes humble them≈øelues before him; but if they ≈øuffer them≈øelues to bee tran≈øported with pre≈øumption, and pride, he ea≈øily abateth, and corrects their fury. I will offer no other example to thy con≈øideration, then that of Baiazet the fir≈øt, one of thy Predece≈ø≈øors, who thinking to ≈øcale Heauen with his Armie (which in the iudgement of Man was vnre≈øi≈øtable, but in Gods ≈øight mo≈øt contemptible) liued to ≈øee him≈øelfe vanqui≈øhed, taken, and impri≈øoned, coopt vp in an iron cage, (wherein hee vvas in triumph drawne after the victorious Conquerour, ≈øeruing him for no better then a foot≈øtoole) and hauing no other food, then ≈øuch as was ca≈øt him (like a Dogge) from his Table.

Thinke then with thy ≈øelfe, that hee that vvas ≈øo great, ≈øo pui≈ø≈øant, and ≈øo terrible, may haply by right of Succe≈øsion haue left vnto thee (as beeing de≈øcended from him) the like, or wor≈øe fortune, if thou ≈øhalt dare to continue thy bla≈øphemies again≈øt GOD, and his Beloued Sonne Ie≈øus
Chri≈øt Crucified. Thou doe≈øt mi≈øtake in thinking to lay an a≈øper≈øion vpon vs, by reproaching vnto vs the Cro≈ø≈øe. For Wee account it Our chiefe≈øt honour, and glory; by vertue vvhereof, as the Emperour Con≈øtantine quelled his enemies, Wee hope, and a≈ø≈øured our ≈øelues to bee defended again≈øt thy Fury. Thy proud, and thundering words di≈ømay vs not, our courage is more Ma≈øculine and generous, then ≈øo to bee out-braued. For know, that wee regard not thy threats, but vvith iu≈øt ≈øcorne tread vpon thy pride, and laugh at thy idle terrours, and in ≈øtead of thanking thee for aduerti≈øing vs before thy comming, We bid thee come when thou wilt, thou ≈øhalt bee receiued contrary to thy expectation. Wee haue ≈øteepe Mountaines, and impregnable Rockes that ≈øhall barre thee from entering into our Lands. Thou ≈øhalt finde our Cities, and Ca≈øtles well furni≈øhed with Munition, our Canons mouthes breathing furious fires, our courages inuincible, our blades eager and ≈øharpe, our bodies, as our mindes, prepared to ≈øu≈øtaine the violence of
all ≈øea≈øons, our hearts promi≈øing nothing but victory. And to dazell thine eyes, the glorious Standard of the ble≈ø≈øed Cro≈ø≈øe ≈øhall goe before vs; but aboue all, the Crucified Son of the mo≈øt High God ≈øhal cau≈øe his Angels to conduct vs, and giue vs the victory; He it is ≈øhall bee our Leader, vnder who≈øe protection wee will not feare to braue thee at thy Gates. Thy mi≈øcreant troupes ≈øhall be troden vnderfoote, and their bellies trampled on, and by a happy victory (if thou chance to e≈øcape our conquering Arme) thou ≈øhalt finde thy ≈øelfe pur≈øued vnto the mo≈øt ≈øecret Dens of thy abominable Seralio; thou ≈øhalt ≈øee thy Mo≈øques laid leuell with the ground, thy Muphty, and other the execrable Prie≈øts of thy perfidious Mahomet made Gally-≈ølaues; all tho≈øe traiterous run-a-gates whom thou doe≈øt harbor, ≈øhalt thou ≈øee put to exqui≈øite torments; of all which be mo≈øt a≈ø≈øured. And then ≈øhall bee ≈øet free all tho≈øe poore and mi≈øerable Chri≈øtians, who now lie groning vnder the burthen of thy Tyrannous yoake, who≈øe wofull cryes being mounted to Heauen, haue
iu≈øtly excited the vengeance of God vpon thee, who hath permitted thee to ri≈øe to this height of pride, that thy ruine & de≈øtruction may bee the more exemplar vnto after-ages. To conclude, thou ≈øhalt ≈øee the ≈øeruice of God re-e≈øtabli≈øhed in Greece and A≈øia, which thou doe≈øt now vniu≈øtly v≈øurpe. But if it happen thee to end thy mi≈øerable life in Battell, (which we hope God will grant) be confident, that all the fore≈øaid vengeance ≈øhall en≈øue vpon thy death; And whiles thy wretched Soule lies broiling in the quenchle≈ø≈øe flames of Hell, wee will lift vp our cheerefull voices, and, for the victory obtained ouer thee and thine, ≈øing prai≈øes vnto our God: to whom be all glory for euer.

Know then, O Infidell, that we feare thee not at all, and if thou bee≈øt not wilfully bent to runne headlong vnto thy owne de≈øtruction, be adui≈øed; content, and containe thy ≈øelfe within tho≈øe bounds thou doe≈øt at this pre≈øent v≈øurpe, and if thou ha≈øt any beliefe at al that thy thrice reuerenced Prophet Mahomet could tell a truth, or foretell future euents, then call to minde, that of tho≈øe
thou≈øand yeeres which hee pre≈øcribed for the continuing of thy Sect, there remaine not aboue ≈øixe or ≈øeuen yeeres. This then is the time that the yet vn≈øheathed Sword of the Chri≈øtians affords for thy amendment, that thou mighte≈øt come to the knowledge of the alone True GOD, to wor≈øhip him in his Sonne IESVS CHRIST, wherevnto we once more exhort thee, omitting all other ≈øalutation, and commendation.
